title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.

  • Draws a correctly labeled graph of the short-run Phillips curve ( SRPC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHXgarmWu51MyVXgarqqtubsr4rNCHbcvPDwzYbGeaGqiFv0Je9sqqrpepiYdbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaaeaabaWaaaGcbaGaae4uaiaabkfacaqGqbGaae4qaaaa@3352@ ).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the expected inflation rate is greater than 1% and/or does not explain that the actual unemployment rate (7%) is greater than the natural rate of unemployment (5%); and/or it does not explain that the economy is in a recession.

The response states that the expected inflation rate is greater than 1% and explains that the actual unemployment rate (7%) is greater than the natural rate of unemployment (5%); or the response explains that the economy is in a recession.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not include either of the criteria below.

  • Calculates the maximum change in aggregate demand as $180 billion and shows the work.

    Maximum Δ in AD=−$20 billion× −0.9 1−0.9 =−$20 billion×−9 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@630D@

    =$200 billion MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3BAC@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not show point Z on the SRPC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHXgarmWu51MyVXgarqqtubsr4rNCHbcvPDwzYbGeaGqiFv0Je9sqqrpepiYdbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaaeaabaWaaaGcbaGaae4uaiaabkfacaqGqbGaae4qaaaa@3352@ to the left of point X on the graph from part (a).

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that aggregate demand would increase and/or does not explain that the increase in disposable income would increase consumption spending.
The response states that aggregate demand would increase and explains that the increase in disposable income would increase consumption spending.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not accurately include any of the criteria below.

  • States that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right and explains that input prices (e.g., nominal wages) and/or inflationary expectations will decrease.

  • States that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left.

  • States that the actual unemployment rate will decrease.

The response does not accurately include two of the criteria below.

  • States that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right and explains that input prices (e.g., nominal wages) and/or inflationary expectations will decrease.

  • States that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left.

  • States that the actual unemployment rate will decrease.

The response does not accurately include one of the criteria below.

  • States that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right and explains that input prices (e.g., nominal wages) and/or inflationary expectations will decrease.

  • States that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left.

  • States that the actual unemployment rate will decrease.

The response accurately includes all the criteria below.

  • States that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right and explains that input prices (e.g., nominal wages) and/or inflationary expectations will decrease.

  • States that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left.

  • States that the actual unemployment rate will decrease.
